entry.title: Quiz 4: Inference and Logic
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Scientific Inference and Logic.
Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time.
Push all your answers to quiz/4/ folder in your Github project.


  1. Name and describe briefly the steps involved in a scientific inference.

    Answer:

    1. Observational data collection and reduction.
    2. Hypothesis formation.
    3. Calibration.
    4. Validation.
    5. Prediction.

  2. What is the relationship between data and reality? Can we observe reality?
    (Hint: Recall the discussions we had early in the semester during the first lecture series. Remember the pyramid of scientific inference.)

    Answer:
    Data is what we observe. Reality is what we never observed because it is always obfuscated with noise.

  3. What is the difference between model validation and calibration?

    Answer:
    Calibration is about finding the best-fit parameters of the model and validation is about validating the predictions of the model on a test dataset.

  4. Name the three pillars of science.

    Answer:
    Theory, Experiment, Computation.

  5. Describe three different major applications of the third pillar of science with respect to the first two.
    (Hint: Recall the discussions we had early in the semester during the first lecture series. Where and how could the third pillar replace the other pillars?)

    Answer:

    1. Simulations can serve as theory where not available.
    2. Simulations can serve as experimental data where not available.
    3. Simulations can be used to predict quantities that are not readily or currently measurable.

  6. Name the two different categories of logical reasoning and provide and example of each class.

    Answer:

    1. Deductive reasoning: If A is true, then B is true.
    2. Plausible reasoning: If A is true, then B is more likely to be true.

  7. Is logical implication the same as physical causation? Explain with an example.

    Answer:
    No. “The sky is rainy” implies that “the sky is cloudy”. However, rainy sky did not physically cause the cloudy sky.

  8. Who is the Boolean algebra named after?

    Answer:
    George Boole

  9. Represent the logical conjunction via a Venn Diagram.

    Answer:
    See the the lecture notes.

  10. Represent the logical disjunction via a Venn Diagram.

    Answer:
    See the the lecture notes.

  11. What does it mean if two propositions have the same truth value?

    Answer:
    See the the lecture notes.

  12. Display the logical implication $A \Rightarrow B$ via a Venn diagram.

    Answer:
    See the the lecture notes.

  13. Recall the Boolean algebra’s fundamental identities. Show that,

    \(\overline{C(A + B)} \equiv \overline{C} + \overline{A} ~ \overline{B}\)

    Answer:
    See the the lecture notes.

  14. Show, via Venn diagrams, that $\overline{AB} \not\equiv \overline{A}~\overline{B}$.

    Answer:
    See the the lecture notes.

  15. Extra Credit. Show, via Venn diagrams, that $\overline{A + B} \not\equiv \overline{A}~+~\overline{B}$.

    Answer:
    See the the lecture notes.

Quiz 4: Inference and Logic was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2022 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on November 02, 2022.

entry.title: Quiz 3: Data Visualization
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Data Visualization.
Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time.
Push all your answers to quiz/3/ folder in your Github project.


  1. what are aesthetics in data visualization? Name a few aesthetics that can appear in a data visualization.

    Answer:
    All data visualizations map data values into quantifiable features of the resulting graphic. We refer to these features as aesthetics.
    Examples: Position, shape, size, color, line width, line type, etc.

  2. Name the two major classes of aesthetics.

    Answer:
    Any of the following:
    continuous vs. discrete.
    quantitative vs. qualitative.
    numerical vs. categorical.
    ordered vs. unordered.

  3. What is the difference between factors and levels?

    Answer:
    You may think of data as numbers, but numerical values are only two out of several types of data we may encounter.
    In addition to continuous and discrete/numerical values, data can come in the form of discrete categories, in the form of dates or times.
    When data is numerical we also call it quantitative and when it is categorical we call it qualitative.
    Variables holding qualitative data are factors, and the different categories are called levels. The levels of a factor are most commonly without order (as in the example of “dog”, “cat”, “fish”).
    But factors can also be ordered, when there is an intrinsic order among the levels of the factor (as in the example of “good”, “fair”, “poor”).

  4. Name the two major types of data and provide an example for each category.

    Answer:
    Any of the following:
    continuous vs. discrete.
    quantitative vs. qualitative.
    numerical vs. categorical.
    ordered vs. unordered.
    See the table of temperature data in the lecture notes for examples.

  5. What is the common name for variables holding data?

    Answer:
    factors.

  6. Provide examples of ordered and unordered data.

    Answer:
    See the table of temperature data in the lecture notes for examples.

  7. What kinds of axes in a plot should be represented with the same units and grid size?

    Answer:
    Data types that are of the same nature should have the same grid sizes on the corresponding axes.
    For example, temperature in Celsius on both X and Y axes.
    See the lecture notes for illustrations.

  8. Describe an example scenario where transforming the axes of the plot results in better visualizations.

    Answer:
    How about visualization of the population of the counties within the state of Texas that we discussed in class?
    See the lecture notes for more examples.

  9. What kind of data set can be best visualized in polar coordinates?

    Answer:
    Periodic.

  10. Name four different color scales and explain their most appropriate usage.

    Answer:
    Accent color scale, for emphasis.
    Sequential color scale, for ordered data.
    Qualitative color scale, for categorical data.
    Diverging color scale for opposing data (have two extremes).

  11. Professional Data Scientists tend to avoid 3D plots in their visualizations. Why?

    Answer:
    It does not add any extra information to visualizations, while creating confusion and hiding data.

  12. Recall our class discussions on the kinds of data, for example, numerical vs. categorical.
    Describe an example dataset that could be classified as either numerical or categorical, depending on how it is represented.

    Answer:
    How about the months of a year?
    If it is numbers, then it is numerical/discrete.
    If it is month names, then it is qualitative/categorical.

  13. Is color a categorical/unordered or quantitative/ordered aesthetics?

    Answer:
    Both, depending on what color scale is being used.
    More details:
    Accent color scale, for emphasis.
    Sequential color scale, for ordered data.
    Qualitative color scale, for categorical data.
    Diverging color scale for opposing data (have two extremes).

  14. Which kind of geographical map better represents the reality (order the maps from the best to the worst): Robinson, Cartesian, Winkel Triple?

    Answer:
    Winkel Triple, Robinson, Cartesian.

  15. Which one of the following three coordinates are valid and can be used to represent data?

    Answer
    All three are valid because all three can map every single data point to a single point on the coordinates axes.
    As long as the two coordinates axes are not along the same direction, the coordinates system they construct is valid.

  16. Best visualization coloring.

    Answer:
    The second one is more appropriate because color-blinded people can recognize the colors too.

  17. US cities temperatures.

    Answer:
    See the question page.

  18. Colorscale classes.

    Answer:
    a) qualitative.
    b) sequential.
    c) diverging.
    d) accent.

  19. US states population growth.

    Answer:
    See the question page.

  20. A wrong visualization.

    Answer:
    The axis labels are tilted.

  21. A wrong visualization.

    Answer:
    Age cannot be negative.

  22. An Excel Bar plot.

    Answer:
    See the question page.

  23. This graph displays the global land temperature anomaly of earth over the past 300 years. The vertical axis basically tells use how hot Earth has been in a given year compared to the average temperature during 1951-1980? Just by looking a this graph, do you think if the temperature of Earth will increase or decrease in the following decades? Approximately, how much hotter or cooler do you think Earth will be in 2050 with respect to the average temperature during 1951-1980 (the zero anomaly temperature)? Express your answer in units of Celsius.

    Answer: Roughly 2.5 Celsius hotter.

  24. (Extra Credit). Recall our class discussion on numbers. Could you count all real or integer numbers that exist if you were given infinite time to do so? Why?

    Answer: Yes. One can count all integers.
    No. There are uncountably infinite real numbers.

  25. (Extra Credit). How would you distinguish exponential behavior vs. power-law behavior (function) in a 2-dimensional plot like this one?

    Answer: An exponential curve looks like a line only when the X-axis is plotted on log-scale. A power-law curve looks like a line only when both the X- and Y- axes are plotted on log-scale.

Quiz 3: Data Visualization was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2022 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on October 19, 2022.

entry.title: Lecture 2: Data Visualization Techniques
entry.content:
Lecture objectives:
By the end of this lecture you will,

  1. learn all about the fundamentals of data visualization,
  2. learn all about the different kinds of visualizations,
  3. be able to identify the different elements of visualizations,
  4. be able to make simple visualizations of data via Excel software,
  5. be able to use color pallets professionally and fairly in data visualizations,

This lecture aims at providing a brief overview of data visualization techniques.

  • Data Visualization

Lecture 2: Data Visualization Techniques was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2022 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on October 05, 2022.

entry.title: Quiz 2: Programming History
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of programming history.
Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time.
Push all your answers to quiz/2/ folder in your Github project.


  1. What is the name of the fastest part of a computer memory?

    Answer: Register

  2. What is the slowest kind of computer storage device?

    Answer: External or Hard drive.

  3. Name the hierarchy of the memory of modern computers, from the smallest to the largest memory size?

    Answer: Register, L1, L2, L3, RAM, External or Hard drive.

  4. What is smallest unit of information in computers? (Hint: Recall our computer programming lecture)

    Answer: bit.

  5. Why humans have chosen the binary numbers (0 and 1) to represent data in computers?

    Answer: Because binary information is readily representable by electric currents.

  6. What is the typical speed of contemporary computer registers?

    Answer: On the order of nanoseconds.

  7. What decade was the first digital computer built?

    Answer: 1940’

  8. What is a fixed program computer?

    Answer: Early models of computers that could only perform certain tasks.

  9. Name an example of modern-day fixed program computer.

    Answer: Calculators.

  10. What is the difference between declarative and imperative knowledge?

    Answer: Declarative knowledge involves statements of fact. Imperative knowledge is about how to accomplish something, or basically, is a recipe on how to do something, known as algorithm in scientific terminology.

  11. What class of human knowledge algorithms belong to?

    Answer: Imperative knowledge.

  12. What is a computer bug?

    Answer: An error in program that has to be resolved for successful execution of the program.

  13. What is a compiler? (Hint: Recall the glossary of our lectures)

    Answer: A software that translates an entire high-level program into a lower-level language to make it executable.

  14. What is the name of the first digital computer?

    Answer: ENIAC.

  15. Name a computer programming language whose evolution and popularity is tightly coupled with the field of Bioinformatics.

    Answer: Python.

  16. Name a computer programming language whose evolution and popularity is tightly coupled with the field of Numerical Computing, Atmospheric Science, Plasma Sciences, and Aerospace Engineering, among others.

    Answer: Fortran.

  17. Name the five major components of a modern digital computer.

    Answer: input device, CPU, main memory, external storage, output device.

  18. Name an example of fixed-program computer.

    Answer: Calculators.

  19. Order the following languages chronologically according to their birth date. (Hint: Use the diagrams from our lecture notes)
    Java, COBOL, C++, Python, Fortran, B

    Answer: Fortran, COBOL, B, C++, Java, Python

  20. (A) What is the closest programming language to machine code (i.e., binary code)?

    Answer: Assembly

    (B) Does it need interpretation in order to become machine-comprehensible?

    Answer: Yes. An Assembler interprets the program for the machine.

  21. (A) Name the oldest high-level programming language that is still in active daily use.

    Answer: Fortran

    (B) Approximately how many decades is it old? ($\pm15$ years is acceptable answer. the decade it was created is also an acceptable answer)

    Answer: in 1950s

  22. (A) Name a second-generation programming language.

    Answer: Assembly

    (B) Which language-generation are Fortran, C, C++, MATLAB, Python, R?

    Answer: third, third, third, fourth, fourth, fourth

  23. In what decades C, C++, and MATLAB/Python were created, respectively? (Hint: Use the diagrams from our lecture notes)

    Answer: 1970s, 1980s, 1980s, 1990s

  24. Name an ancestor programming language of C (Hint: Use the diagrams from our lecture notes).

    Answer: B

  25. Name a programming language ancestor of C++ (Hint: Use the diagrams from our lecture notes).

    Answer: C, Simula

  26. Name a programming language ancestor of MATLAB and a programming language ancestor of Python (Hint: Use the diagrams from our lecture notes).

    Answer: Fortran/C

  27. How do you define logarithm? Explain with a simple example just as we did in class.

    Answer: The logarithm in bae of 10, the exponent that if the number 10 is raised to, then it yields the original number. For example, log10(100) = 2.

  28. Extra Credit. Which memory device is longer lasting: magnetic tapes or HDD (Hard-Disk Drives)? How many years approximately each one last (a rough reasonable estimate is good enough)?

    Answer: Magnetic last decades, HHD last around 5-10 years.

Quiz 2: Programming History was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2022 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on October 03, 2022.

entry.title: Homework 2: Programming History
entry.content:
♣ Due Date: Monday October 3, 2022 9:00 AM. This homework aims at giving you some experience with computer hardware and software. Please write your answers in a README.md file and push them all to HW/2/ folder of your repository on GitHub.

  1. What does ENIAC stand for?

  2. Why is everything represented by integers in computers?

  3. What is the name of the fastest part of the computer memory?

  4. What is the slowest storage device in computers (that is typically integrated with computers)?

  5. What is the smallest unit of information in computer science?

  6. (A) What is the closest programming language to machine code (i.e., binary code)?

    (B) Does it need interpretation in order to become machine-comprehensible?

  7. (A) Name the oldest high-level programming language that is still in active daily use.

    (B) Approximately how many decades is it old? ($\pm15$ years is acceptable answer. the decade it was created is also an acceptable answer)

  8. (A) Name a second-generation programming language.

    (B) Which language-generation are Fortran, C, C++, MATLAB, Python, R?

  9. In what decades C, C++, and MATLAB/Python were created, respectively?

  10. Name an ancestor programming language of C.

  11. Name a programming language ancestor of C++.

  12. Name a programming language ancestor of MATLAB and a programming language ancestor of Python.

  13. What are the three common types of errors in computer programs? Provide an example for each category.

  14. Suppose you write a program that has memory leak. What type of programming error you dealing with?

  15. Extra credit: What are the three fundamental components of a Turing-complete language?

  16. Extra credit: How would you distinguish exponential behavior vs. power-law behavior (function) in a 2-dimensional plot?
    Hint: Recall our discussion of the ENAIC project and the relative frequency of keywords such as “computer” in our programming.

Homework 2: Programming History was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2022 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on September 20, 2022.

entry.title: Quiz 1: Intro. Data Science, Version Control Systems
entry.content:
This quiz aims at testing your basic knowledge of Version Control System and some topics discussed in the history of Data Science. Don’t forget to push your answers to your remote repository by the end of quiz time. Push all your answers to quiz/1/ folder in your Github project.

This quiz is open-lecture, however, you are not allowed to consult other resources or people.
Despite the length of the quiz, many of the answers are brief, sometimes a simple YES or NO, so do not elaborate excessively on a particular question. Instead, try to answer all question briefly and correctly.

You have 50 minutes to submit your answers for this quiz, except those who have prior permission for an extra 25 minutes extended time.


  1. Create a README.md within a subfolder named 1 within the quiz folder that you have already created in your GitHub project as part of homework 1. This README.md file will contain the rest of your answers to the following questions. Once you write your answers to all questions in this file, commit this file to your GitHub project before quiz ends at 9:50 AM.

    Answer:
    Watch the recordings of our lectures for instructions on how to do this.

  2. Recall from our lectures that we typically name our read-me files README.md on GitHub.
    What does .md stand for? Why we do prefer to use .md extension for README files on GitHub?

    Answer:
    The abbreviation md stands for the Markdown language.
    GitHub attempts to process any file with the suffix md as a Markdown-enabled text, and tries to display the rich-text resulting from the processing of the contents of the file instead of the plain text from the file.

  3. Does the git software index and track empty folders in your project?

    Answer:
    NO.

  4. Does every Git project have a .git folder?

    Answer:
    YES.

  5. What is the purpose of the .git folder in Git projects?

    Answer:
    The .git folder contains all information about a given Git project.

  6. Write down the Git command that lists all Git commands for you.

    Answer:

    $ git help -a

  7. What does the Linux Bash command cd do?

    Answer:
    It commands the Bash shell to change directory to another specified path.

  8. What does the Linux Bash command ls -a do?

    Answer:
    It lists all files and folders (including hidden files) in the current Bash path.

  9. What does the Linux Bash command pwd do?

    Answer:
    It displays the path to the current working directory in a Bash environment.

  10. Name four newly emerging branches of science that are growing exponentially fast with respect to the traditional fields of science.

    Answer:
    Neuroscience, Biomedical Science, Bioinformatics, Computational Physics, Data Science

  11. Name and briefly describe the three different areas in a Git project.

    Answer:

    1. Working directory
    2. Staging area
    3. Commit area

  12. What is a Version Control System (VCS)? A brief explanation is enough.

    Answer:
    A software that enables tracking all changes in a project.

  13. Name four modern scientific tools or algorithms that have been growing exponentially fast in popularity over the past decades.

    Answer:
    Artificial Intelligence, MCMC, Machine Learning, Computers

  14. Name 6 major benefits of using distributed VCS as opposed to not using any VCS at all for project indexing and maintenance.

    Answer:
    See this page

  15. Name the three major historical classes of VCS.

    Answer:
    See this page

  16. What is Git and how is it different from GitHub?

    Answer:
    See this page

  17. What does git status command do?

    Answer:
    See this page

  18. What does git push --all command do?

    Answer:
    See this page

  19. What does git pull command do?

    Answer:
    See this page

  20. Name three major modern pillars of science.

    Answer:
    Experiment, theory, computation.

  21. Name three major modern applications of computational and data sciences.

    Answer:
    predictive computing, simulations, data-driven discovery.

  22. What is Markdown?

    Answer:
    A set of rules for text highlighting.

  23. How do you make a text boldface in Markdown?

    Answer:
    By sandwiching the text with double asterisk like **boldface**.

  24. How do you make a text italic in Markdown?

    Answer:
    By sandwiching the text with asterisk like *italic*.

  25. What is the Git command to initialize an empty git project on your local system?

    Answer:
    git init

  26. What was the name of the first digital computer? (an abbreviation is good enough)

    Answer:
    ENIAC

  27. When was the first digital computer built? (an approximate decade is good enough)

    Answer:
    1947

  28. Where was the first digital computer built? (the name of the country is good enough)

    Answer:
    USA

  29. Name the three major components of the field of Data Science?

    Answer:
    coding, statistics, domain field knowledge

  30. You are hopefully on track to become a Data Scientist. Recalling our discussion in class, how would you best define a Data Scientist?

    Answer:
    Data scientist is someone who knows more coding than a statistician and domain expert, knows more statistics than a computer scientist and domain expert, and knows more about domain fields than a computer scientist and statistician.

Quiz 1: Intro. Data Science, Version Control Systems was originally published by Amir Shahmoradi at DATA 1301 - Fall 2022 - MWF 9:00-9:50 - Life Science Building (LS) 101 / Microsoft Teams Virtual Room on September 19, 2022.

entry.title: Homework 1: Version Control Using Git and Github
entry.content:
♣ Due Date: Monday September 19, 2022 9:00 AM. This homework aims at giving you some experience on how to work with Git and GitHub.

  1. Version-control using Git and GitHub ONLY part 1.
  2. Name the three historical types of Version Control Systems.
  3. Which one of the three historical types of Version Control Systems is best and why is it the best?
  4. Briefly describe what the following git commands do.
    a. git pull
    b. git status
    c. git add --all
    d. git commit -m"latest build"
    e. git push --all

    b. quiz
    c. exam
    Inside the hw folder, create another folder named 1. Inside this folder create a README.md file containing your answers to the above questions.

entry.title: Announcement 0: Student-professor connection day
entry.content:
On the first day of our class, we will try to get to know each other and I will attempt to describe my research work and educational background for you, as well as what we should expect from this course. Then I will present the results of the survey that I sent out to you a week ago to assess your programming knowledge, your favorite programming language, and the programming language that you would need for your research. Based on the survey results and your feedback in class, we will decide on the choice of language and the design of this course.

About me, Amir, the instructor

I am a physicist and researcher, and currently a faculty member at the Department of Physics as well as the Data Science Program in The College of Science at The University of Texas at Arlington. You can find more information about me, our group, and our research at cdslab.org. Here is a summary of my life in a few pictures:

I was introduced to the world of information and computer programming around 1991 by my father and elder brother. By the end of elementary school, I was so impressed with and knew enough about computer software to write a few simple computer games in QBasic programming language on our first family personal computer, IBM 386. Here is an example of how computer games looked liked 30 years ago.


I never imagined a day I would use computer programming for scientific purposes. Nevertheless, there has been almost no single day that I have not used scientific programming for my work and research, ever since I entered graduate school.

My research topics

The following are a few examples of what I do nowadays as part of my scientific research at UT Austin.

Theoretical Astrophysics

While my current focus of research is mathematical modelling of tumor growth and Monte Carlo samplers, I am and have been working in multiple branches of science and engineering for several years, from the subatomic world of elementary particles, to the microscopic world of biological macromolecules, to astrophysical phenomena occurring on the grandest scales of the observable Universe.

For several years of my research, I have been working on understanding Gamma-Ray Bursts (GRB) and their physics. Below is a movie of the moment a Short-duration GRB is generated from the merger of a binary Neutron star system.



Theoretical Biology, Bioinformatics

I have also worked for a few years in the field of bioinformatics and evolutionary biology. The overarching goal in the field of protein bioinformatics and biophysics is to understand how proteins fold into their unique structure, and what determines the stability of the protein 3D structure.






One of the workhorses of this field, is therefore molecular dynamic simulation to probe the dynamics of proteins and their interactions with other molecules. The following is a 1.5ns molecular dynamics simulation of Human Influenza H1 Hemagglutinin protein (1RD8, chains AB).


Petroleum Engineering


Computational Oncology

What you see in the figures below, is a representation of the growth of Glioblastoma tumor cells in a Rat’s brain over time.








The temporal evolution of the growth of Glioma tumor in rat






Monte Carlo Simulation and Integration Methods

One of the fields on which my research is currently focused, is developing Monte Carlo optimizer/sampler and integrator algorithms for Bayesian inverse problems.

Development of Monte Carlo sampling algorithms

Below you see example animations of two Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) samplers, both of which sample a double Gaussian-peak function, but with different MCMC sampling parameters.
